You are given a sequence of $n$ integers $a_1, a_2, ..., a_n$. You are also given $x$ integers $1, 2, ..., x$.

You need to insert each of the extra integers into the sequence $a$. Each integer can be inserted at the beginning, at the end, or between any elements of the sequence.

The score of the resulting sequence $a'$ is the sum of absolute differences of adjacent elements in it:  
$\sum_{i=1}^{n+x-1} |a'_i - a'_{i+1}|$

What is the smallest possible score of the resulting sequence $a'$?


Input:

* The first line contains $t$ ($1 \le t \le 10^4$) — the number of test cases.
* The first line of each test case contains two integers $n$ and $x$ ($1 \le n, x \le 2 \cdot 10^5$) — the length of the sequence and the number of extra integers.
* The second line of each test case contains $n$ integers $a_1, a_2, ..., a_n$ ($1 \le a_i \le 2 \cdot 10^5$).
* The sum of $n$ over all test cases doesn't exceed $2 \cdot 10^5$.

Output:

For each test case, print a single integer — the smallest sum of absolute differences of adjacent elements of the sequence after you insert the extra integers into it.

You are given a list of numbers and a set of additional numbers. You can insert the additional numbers into the list at any position.  What is the smallest possible sum of the absolute differences between each pair of consecutive numbers in the resulting list?
